Award.AwardTitle: RET Site: Cyber Security Initiative for Nevada Teachers (CSINT)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This funding establishes a new Research Experience for Teachers (RET) Site at the University of Nevada, Reno (UNR). The primary objective of this RET site is to explore unique ways to engage middle and high school teachers in summer research experiences that emphasize cybersecurity. The teachers will spend six weeks in the summer participating in research experiences and developing classroom modules and materials which will be implemented in their classrooms during the academic year. The UNR team will use inter-personal role-playing and cybersecurity games to help the teachers learn about cybersecurity and its importance to our nation. The project involves a partnership between the university, the school districts in the surrounding Nevada counties, industrial associates, and the Nevada Department of Education. The project will develop a community of teachers who are passionate about cybersecurity and who can translate this excitement to their students through engaging, high-quality inquiry learning experiences. This RET Site is co-funded by the Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace (SaTC) program.

The project is anchored by a research area this is compelling and exciting for teachers and K-12 students and by faculty team that has demonstrated expertise in both research and education. The goals of the project are to: recruit a cohort of middle and high school teachers interested in introducing cybersecurity and computer science topics into their classrooms; engage the recruited teachers in research experiences with applications in various modern day systems and security; develop instructional modules that can be incorporated into a variety of grades/classes; initiate collaboration and engagement with all schools in Nevada and other stakeholders in the country to promote and disseminate the results to a large group of middle and high school teachers; and sustain long term partnerships between the RET Site teacher participants, the UNR mentor team and industry partners, in order to bring the excitement of computing, problem solving and research to students and encourage them to pursue STEM related careers. The site features projects that are teacher accessible as well as connected to current research and practice. The RET site includes sound evaluation and dissemination plans that will provide models for integrating cybersecurity concepts into the middle and high school curricula. Teachers will develop and hone their research, communication, and presentation skills, all of which are essential to their professional growth and success. The project will build the technical capacity of teachers so they are capable of developing and implementing new, exciting inquiry-based learning activities at their schools. The project team will disseminate the project materials through the TeachEngineering digital library and a dedicated local website and server repository that will be shared with a wider audience of teachers at annual workshops and meetings. The team will also disseminate project results through high-quality journals and professional meetings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project proposed "RET Site: Cyber Security Initiative for Nevada Teachers (CSINT)" to explore unique ways to engage Middle and High School (MsHs) teacher participants in STEM education in research areas that are of "high state and national priority" and to sustain long-term research and education partnerships between participants, faculty and industry partners. The intellectual focus of CSINT has been research in computer science and engineering (CSE) fields with particular emphasis on cybersecurity.

The objectives were to: (1) recruit a cohort of middle and high school (MsHs) teachers interested in introducing cybersecurity and CSE topics into their classrooms; (2) engage the recruited teachers in CSE research principles with applications in various modern-day systems and security; (3) develop instructional modules that can be incorporated in a variety of grades/classes; (4) initiate collaboration and engagement with all schools in Nevada and other stakeholders in the country to promote and disseminate the results to a large group of MsHs teachers; and (5) sustain long term partnerships between CSINT teacher participants, the UNR mentor team, and industry partners in order to help bring the excitement of computing, problem solving and research to a large segment of students and encourage them to pursue STEM related careers.

The findings of the project are contributing to understand and analyze how to:

1) engage the talented, diverse teacher participants from across different counties in an active learning process and to expose them to the theory and application of research with a focus on cybersecurity;

2) develop interdisciplinary instructional modules that can be incorporated in a variety of classes by fostering a holistic approach through collaboration across disciplines;

3) have opportunities for hands-on transformative experiences on state-of-the-art cybersecurity testbed; and

4) sustain long term research/education partnerships, and to help bring the excitement of computing, problem solving and research to the teacher participants and their students and encourage them to pursue cybersecurity related careers.

More specifically, the key outcomes have been:

The project has helped the UNR RET program and the teacher participants, and it has been able to help the students, the schools, the school districts, and state administrators in understanding the significance of cybersecurity research and education from the early stage.

The project has given us opportunity to envision a pathway program from Nevada school into UNR. The conversation has started to open up avenues on to develop a six-year program of study for computer science emphasized with cybersecurity. This would include a direct pipeline of high school students to UNR. The program of study would leverage both dual credit and program outreach to expose and support students to enroll in post-secondary programs.

Thousands of students are now getting exposed to cybersecurity awareness from their middle and high school level due to the impact of this RET site.

Many of the schools have started their own cyberclub inspired by UNR cyber club and started taking part in cyber league and Capture the flag-style competitions. The teachers taking part in RET site activities have led their way for the school cyber clubs.

The state of Nevada has started Cyberstart in 2017 and girls go cyberstart in 2018 where many of the participating schools and their newly started cyberclubs along with their teachers participated. This has definitely opened up a new awareness among the teachers, schools, districts and the state.

The project has enabled us to develop new cybersecurity programs such as Cybersecurity Graduate Certificate and Cybersecurity Master's program at University of Nevada, Reno and making the UNR Cybersecurity Center a nationwide prominent Center.
